unnormalised: So, someone asked about the future of software dev in India. Well, from what I've seen, it's booming! I remember back in '05, landing my first job after my MCA. The tech was so different then. We were mostly doing outsourced stuff, working with legacy systems using tech like VB6 and .NET 2.0. Salaries were okayish, around Rs. 1.8 LPA starting. Now, freshers are getting offers of 8 LPA and upwards, especially if they're good with Python, React or know things like cloud computing (AWS, Azure).
normalised: So, someone asked about the future of software development in India. Well, from what I've seen, it's booming! I remember back in two thousand and five, landing my first job after my M-C-A. The tech was so different then. We were mostly doing outsourced stuff, working with legacy systems using tech like V-B six and dot N-E-T two point zero. Salaries were okayish, around rupee one point eight L-P-A starting. Now, freshers are getting offers of eight L-P-A and upwards, especially if they're good with Python, React or know things like cloud computing (A-W-S, Azure).

unnormalised: The biggest change, I think, is the focus on product development now. You see so many Indian startups building their own software, and they need skilled developers. Plus, companies like TCS and Infosys are moving up the value chain, doing more cutting-edge work. My cousin, Aisha, joined a startup in Bangalore, working on AI stuff. She tells me they are using Kubernetes and Docker, stuff I didn't even know existed back when I started! She gets paid a lot and even has stock options; this was unheard of in the early 2000s.
normalised: The biggest change, I think, is the focus on product development now. You see so many Indian startups building their own software, and they need skilled developers. She tells me they are using Kubernetes and Docker, stuff I didn't even know existed back when I started! She gets paid a lot and even has stock options; this was unheard of in the early two thousands.

unnormalised: And the best part? The whole world opened up. Remote work is common; you can work from anywhere, like my village in Kerala, for a US or European company. I think the skills we are developing in India will become much more global. But definitely learn to code first, get that certification. The future depends on guys who know more than just "Hello World!".
